questions.question:
Question 1: The term ametropia refers to all except 
.
questions.explanation:
The term ametropia refers to conditions of refractive error. Emmetropia refers to an optically normal eye. The term ametropia includes conditions such as • Myopia (shortsightedness) • Hypermetropia (longsightedness) • Astigmatism 57 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A small kid is brought for examination due to difficulty reading from the board at school. 
Visual acuity was 20/60 in both eyes. His vision got corrected with concave lens spectacles. 
Which of the following is the most common cause of this refractive error?

options.a: Increased anteroposterior diameter of the eye ball
options.d: Increase in the refractive index of lens

questions.explanation:
Poor vision for distance (difficulty reading from board) that is corrected with concave lens 
spectacles suggest that the child has myopia. The most common cause of myopia 
(shortsightedness) is increased anteroposterior length of the eyeball. Myopia is a type of refractive error seen when the parallel rays of light from infinity are focused in 
front of the retina when accomodation is at rest.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following range defines moderate myopia?
questions.explanation: Moderate myopia is defined when the refractive error is between -3D and -6D. Note: Myopia according to age of onset: • Congenital: Present at birth • Youth onset: 2–20 years of age • Early adult onset: 20–40 years of age • Late adult onset: >40 years of age

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following myopias is not associated with high degree of refractive error?
questions.explanation:
School myopia or simple myopia is associated with a low to moderate degree of refractive error. Simple myopia is the most common type of myopia. It results from a normal biological variation 
in the development of the eye i.e. increased anteroposterior diameter of eyeball or increased 
curvature of the cornea. 58 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Options A and D: Pathological/Degenerative/Progressive myopia occurs due to degenerative 
changes in the retina, leading to a high degree of refractive error. Option B: Congenital myopia is associated with congenital anomalies of the eye, and a high degree 
of refractive error. Note: Other types of myopia include: 1. Nocturnal myopia: Accommodation is induced by low contrast in dim illumination 2. Induced myopia: Temporary and reversible myopia due to external agents (e.g., 
pilocarpine-induced accommodation spasm)/variations in blood sugar levels 3. Pseudomyopia: Inappropriately excessive accommodation due to overstimulation/ciliary spasm.

questions.question:
Question 5: A woman comes to the ophthalmology OPD because of having vision difficulties for the last 3 
months. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen. Which of the following 
is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a fundus typical of pathological myopia due to the stretching of the retina. The tigroid appearance or tessellated appearance of the fundus can be appreciated. As the eye 
enlarges, the retinal pigment epithelium becomes thinner, resulting in: • A tessellated (checkered) appearance of the fundus • Increased visibility of the choroidal vasculature Other features of the myopic fundus are as follows: • Lacquer cracks are spontaneous ruptures of the elastic lamina of Bruch’s membrane. It appears 
yellowish-white. it is usually located in the posterior pole. • Annular gray shadow around the optic disc • Lattice degeneration • Foster Fuchs spots • Cystoid degeneration • Total retinal atrophy 59 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A woman with pathological myopia visits the ophthalmology OPD for an annual eye check-up. 
What is the least likely finding to be seen on her ophthalmologic examination?
questions.explanation:
The shallow anterior chamber is not a feature of pathological myopia. Signs of pathological myopia include the following: • Prominent eyeballs • Large cornea • Deep anterior chamber (AC) • Fundus picture • Large, pale optic disc with the temporal myopic crescent • Degenerative changes in retina and choroid • Foster Fuchs spots (blackish spots due to retinal pigment epithelial hyperplasia) • Lattice degeneration • Cystoid degeneration • Total retinal atrophy • Posterior staphyloma • Degenerative changes in the vitreous—posterior vitreous detachment 60 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is true about degenerative myopia?

options.a: It is seen in less than 6 dioptres of myopia.
options.b: It is more common in males than in females.
options.c: Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment.
options.d: The condition has no racial prediliction.

questions.explanation:
The statement that is true for degenerative myopia is that myopic degeneration can lead to retinal 
detachment. Degenerative myopia is seen in more than 6 dioptres of myopia. It is more common in females as 
compared to males. The condition has a racial predilection; it is more common in Jews and 
Japanese people, and most cases are of genetic origin. Changes seen in degenerative myopia are myopic crescent, rhegmatogenous retinal detachment 
(due to degenerative changes in the periphery of the retina with subsequent tear) and floaters (due 
to degenerative changes in the vitreous).

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is the most common complication of pathological myopia?
questions.explanation:
Macular degeneration is the most common complication of myopia, followed by rhegmatogenous 
retinal detachment. Complications of pathological myopia include the following: • Macular degeneration • Retinal detachment • Complicated cataract • Vitreous hemorrhage • Choroidal hemorrhage • Strabismus fixus convergence 61 
Sold by @itachibot • Primary open-angle glaucoma, which is not a complication, but reported to occur in association 
with pathological myopia.

questions.question:
Question 9: While performing the following procedure on a 35-year-old male at a distance of 1 meter, you 
found out that the red reflex was not moving with the movement of the instrument. How will 
you interpret your findings?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows the procedure of retinoscopy (skiascopy) being performed. As the red 
reflex is not moving with the movement of the retinoscope, the patient is interpreted as 
having myopia of 1D. Retinoscopy is an objective method of determining the error of refraction. It is based on the 
principle that when light is reflected from a mirror into the eye, the direction in which tlhe light 
will travel across the pupil depends upon the refractive stale of the eye. Interpretation of 
retinoscopy done at 1m is: • No movement of red reflex: Myopia of 1D • Movement of red reflex with retinoscope: Emmetropia, hypermetropia, myopia less than 1D • Movement of red reflex against the retinoscope: Myopia more than 1D

questions.question:
Question 10: A worried mother brought her son for vision examination when she noticed him reading a 
book too closely. She says he also narrows his eyes while watching television. Examination 
revealed myopia. Which of the following lens should be prescribed to correct this child's 
vision?
questions.explanation:
Concave lenses are used for correcting myopic errors. 62 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option A: Convex lenses are used in the correction of hypermetropic eye and presbyopic eye. Option C: Cylindrical lenses are used in the correction of astigmatism.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following statement about the management of myopia is false?

options.a: In high myopia, it is better to slightly under-correct for distance.
options.b: Concave lens is used to correct myopia.
options.c: Contact lens provides a wider field and larger image size as compared to glasses.
options.d: Myopia must never be under-corrected with spectacles.

questions.explanation:
The false statment is that myopia must never be under-corrected with spectacles. In fact, it is 
better to slightly under-correct cases of high myopia. Concave lens are used to correct myopia. In high myopia, it is better to slightly under-correct to 
avoid the problem of near vision and that of minification of images. Contact lens are preferred in 
high myopia as they provide a wider field and larger image size as compared to glasses.

questions.question:
Question 12: A college student is fed up with wearing spectacles for her myopia. During her annual eye 
checkup, she asks the ophthalmologist for eye surgery to get rid of the glasses. Which of the 
following is not a surgical option to correct her refractive error?
questions.explanation:
Conductive keratoplasty is a cornea-based surgical procedure used in the correction of 
hypermetropia. Surgical procedures are undertaken after the stabilization of myopia which usually occurs after 18 
years of age.

questions.question:
Question 13: 53 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following laser is used in the treatment of myopia?
questions.explanation:
Excimer laser is used in the treament of myopia. Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is the most popular treatment modality for myopia. 
It is performed using an excimer laser. Surgical correction is only done in individuals who have a 63 
Sold by @itachibot stable refractive error for at least 1 year. Corneal thinning disorders must be ruled out prior to this 
procedure.

questions.question:
Question 14: A mother asks for LASIK surgery for the correction of her 15-year-old daughter's myopia. 
Which of the following is not an eligibility criterion for this procedure?

options.a: Stable refraction for the past 1 year

questions.explanation:
Age of 15 years is not a criterion for LASIK surgery. LASIK surgery is performed after 18 years of 
age. Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser in individuals aged 
> 18 years who have a stable refractive error for 1 year. It is done in individuals who have had 
unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment. Corneal-thinning disorders such as 
keratoconus must be ruled out before this procedure.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is false about the refractive error in which the image is formed behind 
the retina?
questions.explanation:
Hypermetropia is the refractive error where the image is formed behind the retina. In 
hypermetropia, near point becomes distant. The near point or punctum proximum is the nearest point at which small objects can be seen 
clearly. It recedes with age. Hypermetropia is also called long-sightedness since patients are able to focus distant objects more 
easily than near objects. Accommodative convergent squint in children is a complication of 
uncorrected long-standing hypermetropia. The fundus may show pseudopapillitis. Hypermetropia is classified into the following types: • Latent hypermetropia: Masked by the tone of the ciliary body • Facultative hypermetropia: Masked by the voluntary accommodative effort of the person • Absolute hypermetropia: Apparent/manifest 64 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: You have been asked to perform fundoscopy by your senior resident in one of his patients 
diagnosed with hypermetropia. Which of the following options represent the findings that 
could be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Shot silk appearance with pseudopapillitis can be seen on fundal examination 
of the hypermetropic eye. Hypermetropia is a refractive error of the eye in which parallel rays of light from infinity focus 
behind the retina when accommodation is at rest. Fundoscopy findings in hypermetropia include 
shot silk appearance (retina may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections) and 
pseudopapillitis (optic disc is small, hypervascular, with ill-defined margins without disc edema). Other signs of hypermetropia include small eyeball, small cornea and short anteroposterior length 
of the eyeball. Convex lens (plus lens) is used for the correction of hypermetropia.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following grades of error defines high hypermetropia?
questions.explanation: High hypermetropia is defined as an error of >5D.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 50-year-old man wants to undergo surgery for hypermetropia. All of the following are 
options to treat his refractive error except?
questions.explanation:
Photorefractive keratectomy is not the surgical modality of the treatment of hypermetropia. Photorefractive keratectomy is a laser ablation technique for the correction of myopia. An excimer 
laser is used to cause flattening of the central cornea. 65 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This 
finding is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows convergent squint or esotropia, which is commonly seen in children with 
hyperopia, also known as hypermetropia. Esotropia results due to increased accommodative effort in cases where there is under correction 
of hypermetropia. The condition may be prevented by full hypermetropic correction. If the child is 
unable to wear the glasses due to flat nasal bridge or if the child is less than 2 years old, the 
accommodation may be treated with drugs. Miotic drugs with anticholinesterase activity such as 
di-isopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) or echothiophate can be used in these children. Further 
treatment may include orthotropic training or surgical correction of the squint.

questions.question:
Question 20: A boy was brought by his parents for an eye exam. He has been having headaches, nausea, 
and visual discomfort since he started school. His ophthalmological examination revealed a 
refractive error of + 2D in the right eye and -1 D in the left eye. His fundus appears to be 
normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A child with refractive error of + 2D in the right eye and -1 D in the left eye has anisometropia. Anisometropia is the condition wherein the total refractive power of the two eyes is unequal. A 
difference of up to 2.5 D between two eyes is well tolerated. If the anisometropia exceeds 2.5D, 
ambylopia may develop. Contact lenses are preferred for treatment due to less optical defects as 
compared to glasses.

questions.question: Question 21: What is aniseikonia?

options.a: The horizontal meridian is more myopic.
options.b: The vertical meridian is more myopic.
options.c: The vertical meridian is more hyperopic.
options.d: The horizontal meridian is more hyperopic.

questions.explanation:
Aniseikonia is a condition in which there is a difference in the size of the image formed by the two 
eyes. Up to 5–8% aniseikonia is well tolerated. Treatment includes contact lens in patients with phakia 
and intraocular lens implantation in patients with aphakia. 66 
Sold by @itachibot Astigmatism and Errors of Accomodation
